Apple (AAPL) will pause US sales of its Series 9 and Ultra 2 smartwatches from this week as it awaits a decision related to the US International Trade Commission's order that may potentially ban imports of the devices, several media outlets reported Monday.
Tech giant Apple Inc. (AAPL) has announced that it will halt sales of its flagship Apple Watch models in the United States.
The Apple Watch Ultra 2 and Apple Watch Series 9 will no longer be available to order from Apple's website in the U.S.
The decision is based on an ITC ruling related to a patent dispute between Apple and medical technology company Masimo around the Apple Watch's blood oxygen sensor technology.

APPLE INC (AAPL) is a large-cap growth stock in the Communications Equipment industry.
Shares of the tech giant have skyrocketed more than 50% this year.
The company beat Wall Street earnings estimates in each of its quarterly updates in 2023.
The company reported better-than-expected Q3 revenue and earnings on Oct. 20, 2023.
The company reported 15% year-over-year revenue growth in the third quarter with diluted earnings per share jumping 28%.
Intel's Meteor Lake PC CPUs officially launched on Dec. 14, with some laptops built around the new chips already available.
Intel claims in creative applications like those from Adobe, Meteor Lake can deliver anywhere from 1.2 times to 5.4 times the performance of a comparable AMD Ryzen CPU.
Intel demonstrated LLaMa2-7B, a smaller large language model capable of text generation, successfully running on a Meteor Lake system using the CPU, GPU, and AI hardware.
Should you invest $1,000 in Intel right now?
Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway first purchased shares of Apple during the first quarter of 2016.
Since Jan. 1 of that year to Dec. 12 of this year, the iPhone maker's stock price has skyrocketed 639%.
Apple shares traded at an average price-to-earnings (P/E) multiple of 10.6.
As of this writing, shares trade at a P/E of 31.8, triple the range that Buffett first purchased them at.
The way things stand, Apple stock just doesn't make for a smart investment.
The Motley Fool has positions in and recommends Apple and Berkshire Hathaway.
Apple was the first to crank its distribution higher. It declared a 4% dividend raise in May, which pushed the quarterly payout to $0.24 per share.
Apple is a cornerstone investment in Berkshire's stock portfolio, to the point where the tech giant comprises a whopping 49% of it.
Bank of America declared a dividend raise of 9%, to $0.24 per share per quarterly distribution.
